body: @tcNickolas Can you file a JIRA for each of the missing package level javadocs? The respective authors can then go through and fix them.
Together with newly added package-info.java (REEF-432) there will be a hundred of package-level missing javadocs. Do we have some kind of higher-level ownership to avoid spamming JIRA that much?
@markusweimer @jwang98052 Would we have more issues to tackle on this PR?

Between ClassHierarchy and AvroNode, I have FromAvroNode/ToAvroNode methods to do the conversion. 
Then I have serialization/deserialization between AvroNode and byte[], string, file, ... with the serialization methods provided by Avro library/JSon. 
Does it make sense?
For the current issues in Hadoop.Avro, I added more testes and put the comments for details. After Avro resolves issue, we should run those test cases to verify it.

The code looks good.
The only problem is Hadoop.Avro has multiple issues. Even I have implemented .Net class hierarchy serializer, the conversion between AvroNode and ClassHierarchy works but serialization for file, byte[], etc still have issues. That would prevent us from integration testing and really use it in REEF. 
For now, we have to keep using protobuffer for Class Hierarchy. 
I would think we should merge the code for both java and C#. Once Hadoop.Avro resolve the issue, we can come back to test it and replace protobuffer with Avro implementation. 
@markusweimer, what do you think?
Review comments have been addressed and pushed in.
Oops! Let's leave it at the module level, then.
@jwang98052 It seems like the push is missing. I just commented on a few issues where you commented they are done, but they are not. Also, I don't see a push here.

We can merge this if it looks good. We only need to gate the removal of protobuf support on having all issues with Avro resolved on both sides. Otherwise, this runs the risk of becoming outdated with new pull requests being merged.
I will test and merge it.
Opps, committed abut forgot to push. Will do it with your latest comments.

This creates build failures as the file name hasn't changed. I believe the source issue is that OS X isn't case sensitive, just case preserving. [This](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10523849/git-changing-capitalization-of-filenames) seems to offer some solutions.

This has a checkstyle violation:

```
[ERROR] src/main/java/org/apache/reef/examples/data/output/OutputServiceREEF.java[123:5] (blocks) RightCurly: '}' should be on the same line.
```

This fails due to a checkstyle issue:

```
[ERROR] src/main/java/org/apache/reef/util/CollectionUtils.java[33] (javadoc) JavadocStyle: First sentence should end with a period.
[ERROR] src/main/java/org/apache/reef/util/CollectionUtils.java[42] (javadoc) JavadocStyle: First sentence should end with a period.
```
